body.name: Satan, Aliens, Go!: A funny sci-fi novel (A Quantum Heart Trilogy Book 1)

productInformation.name: Best Sellers Rank
productInformation.value: #152,450 in Kindle Store (See Top 100 in Kindle Store) #6 in Physics of Time (Kindle Store) #29 in Parodies #158 in Humorous Science Fiction (Kindle Store)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This book made me laugh, and not a gentle exhalation from the nostrils- a genuine giggle and I even snorted a little. I walked around and thought about the funniest parts and laughed again. This is exactly what I want from a book in this economy

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 13, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars I enjoyed it enough to buy the rest of the trilogy
reviews.reviewText: This book is sort of like an adult version of Hitchhiker's Guide. I've read more than one novel like this where the dimensions split open and beings cross over and become part of society. Corrupted Mortal Vessel is a good example. I look forward to finishing the rest of Tsagaris's trilogy.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2019
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A cult book in the making
reviews.reviewText: What a ride! One of the few books that I read from start to end without getting tired, unless it's getting tired from laughing. Satan is an awesome character and everyone in the book blends perfectly around him. There is only one thing left for the story to be awesome: Go Audible! Then a sequel!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars witty, snarky sci-fi
reviews.reviewText: A witty, tongue-in-cheek jaunt through Hell, Earth, and an alien invasion. I found this to be just the thing I needed for a light-hearted sci-fi read. I'm looking forward to the continuing adventures.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars A fun, amusing light read.
reviews.reviewText: If half stars were available, I'd go to 3.5 because this light-hearted romp made me smile and made an enjoyable escape from the slings and arrows of outrageous all that stuff. It bounces along with some clever ideas and droll plot points. Where it fails is in characterization. The personalities and speech styles of most characters are almost interchangeable and much of their motivation is shallow or vague. That matters little if you're just riding along for the jokes, but it does keep the book from rising to the level of deeper SF/F humor. I have no complaints about buying this book and certainly wouldn't discourage anyone else from doing the same.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars This was the very silly story I needed right now
reviews.reviewText: This author must have lived through the 80's, because there were so many references it made me feel right at home. The writing was interesting, fast paced and funny. I didn't think about the pandemic or the election once while reading it. Great distraction and a good read!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars A wild ride
reviews.reviewText: The story jumps around between multiple characters and it might be best to read it in a few days to keep track. It was fun, but to me, not laugh out loud funny. Well worth reading.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Funny. Read this book! So much better than reality!!!
reviews.reviewText: One liner after one liner and tons of great literary and movie/tv hysterical references. I contrast for the sequel! I heartily recommend this book for time spent away from politics, collapsing economies and crazy viruses that we can't do anything about.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 7, 2021
reviews.reviewText: Who ever wrote this book must surely have forgotten their medication but I’d like to have a drink with them.Not laugh out loud funny, but mind twisting funny all the same

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 3, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: Weaker than I was led to expect
reviews.reviewText: It's a dangerous game to compare humorous SciFi with Douglas Adams' books simply because it primes the reader to expect something very good, sadly this isn't. I found it fairly average but having bought the trilogy gave it my most optimistic effort. It's quite funny in places but is inconsistent and suffered an entropy decay arc through all three books. Note to self "don't buy bundled trilogies without reading a good chunk of the first book". The second and third books were progressively weaker and I was glad to finish them.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 14, 2020
reviews.reviewText: Satan and aliens in the same story is different. Well written and has some funny parts to it but not for me.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 28, 2020
reviews.reviewText: Lots of well written nonsense in a christians world Satan makes an appearance and it all downhill from there. Good stuff.
